etymology.description: 牵牛 + 花 = flower of the ‘qiānniú’ (morning glory) plant.
etymology.interpretation: Literally “cowherd/morning‑glory flower”: 牵牛 is an established plant name in Chinese (also ‘to lead an ox’ and the Cowherd star), so the compound denotes the flower of that twining vine that opens in the morning. Often also called 喇叭花 for its trumpet shape.
etymology.simplification: 牵 is the simplified form of 牽, created to reduce stroke count; 牛 and 花 are unchanged. Thus the word simplifies only in the first character.

parts.english: morning glory (plant name); to lead an ox; cowherd (Altair)

examples.chinese: 牵牛花清晨开放(牽牛花清晨開放)，中午就合拢(中午就合攏)。
examples.pinyin: Qiānniúhuā qīngchén kāifàng, zhōngwǔ jiù hélǒng.
examples.english: Morning glories open at dawn and close around midday.

examples.chinese: 孩子们叫它喇叭花(孩子們叫它喇叭花)。
这种藤会攀爬篱笆(這種藤會攀爬籬笆)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè zhǒng téng huì pānpá líbā.
